awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Signal Crosstalk Within Complex Microbial Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbial ecosystems in nature are typically composed of hundreds or thousands of microbial species, heterogeneously distributed in space and time. New experimental and theoretical tools are needed to develop a predictive understanding of the regulatory processes that control the outputs of these complex cellular networks. Current approaches focus on correlations between the components of the system (such as genetic composition, expression levels, metabolite concentrations), however such correlations alone are usually insufficient to develop strategies for robust control of the state and function of diverse microbial communities. In this project the PI will use multiscale approach that combines theoretical predictions with precision experimental tests to quantitatively understand how individual and groups of cells reach decisions to coordinate global behavior within microbial ecosystems. Tackling modern societal challenges related to health, agriculture, and the environment will benefit from a predictive understanding of how multiple components of a network work together, particularly for complex networks involving many densely connected components. To inspire the next generation of scientists to take up problems on the physics of systems and complexity, the PI has partnered with a local science non-profit to design and implement hands-on learning activities related to the biophysics of signal exchange. Students will gain an intuitive understanding of the physical principles that govern cellular networks, including insight into how network properties emerge from the behavior of individuals within a population. Themes of this research will also appear in an undergraduate general education course focused on training undergraduates from diverse background, including non-science majors, in essential quantitative skills intrinsic to the physical sciences.

The PI will examine the exchange of variant quorum sensing signals within diverse microbial networks to understand how signaling interactions between individual strains give rise to emergent properties of the network. An artificial neural network model predicts the impact of crosstalk between cell types on system-level signaling states. The stability of these signal-driven regulatory states will be examined in both models and experiments to gauge the potential to direct the outputs of multispecies networks through perturbations of species composition or signal exchange pathways. This combination of theory and experiment illuminates how systems-level behaviors such as robustness emerge from the collective action of multiple cell types working together.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: 

All around us are communities of microorganisms. Diverse groups of cells live together interact in many ways, including communication through the exchange of molecular signals. Signals produced by one cell are detected by other cells, thereby relaying information from one cell to the next and helping to coordinate behaviors that require many cells working together. When microbial communities are diverse, containing many types of cells, individual cells receive a mixture of signals. Predicting the outcomes of signal exchange within such diverse communities of cells will require an understanding of how microbes integrate information from multiple signals and regulate behavior. This project measured the response of bacteria cells to signal exchange within such diverse contexts. Model borrowed from physics were used to predict how cellular communities communicate and collectively coordinate the behavior of cells within the group. This work also examined how communication within communities is influenced by changes in conditions, such as cells types changing in number or being removed from the community, and under what circumstances drastic changes in the behavior of the community should be anticipated. By combining both experiments and models, this project clarified how communication within diverse populations of cells sets the activity of individual cell types. This work was used to inspire the next generation of biophysics students, through outreach work that interfaced with K-12 and undergraduate students.

Intellectual Merit:

There is an increasing need to manipulate and design communities of microbes. This project revealed how communication between different types of bacterial cells influenced the response of each individual cell type and the activity state of the community of as a whole. Signal exchange within communities was modeled as a recurrent neural network, and experimental measurements validated that this model accurately predicts how signal exchange regulates activity within diverse microbial communities. The project also explored the stability of such networks to perturbations, revealing that most network states are robust to fluctuations in community composition or signal concentrations. Perturbations to some networks resulted in large changes in activity, including a percolation transition of activity states within populations that were spatially distributed. The influence of molecular noise, phenotypic memory, and the presence of orthogonal signaling pathways were examined.

Broader Impacts:

Understanding interactions within diverse communities of microorganisms is critical to many emerging technologies in health, agriculture, and the environment. This project has advanced our ability to predict the activity of microbial populations through insights into how signal exchange between microbes sets the behavior of large, diverse groups of cells. These new insights were shared with students of all ages, to inspire them to pursue studies and careers in STEM. Outreach activities included the creation of instructional materials for educators and hands on research experiences for high school and undergraduate students. A new undergraduate course was created to train students from diverse background in a broad range of quantitative skills. Students gained a more intuitive understanding of how physics and biology can work together to dissect complex, real-life problems. The scientific findings of this project have improved our ability to incorporate signal exchange in applications to engineer, predict, or control the activity of complex populations of bacteria.
